Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Reinforced Tension-Line Suture in Colorectal Cancer Surgery

Background: This study aimed to evaluate whether adding a reinforced tension-line (RTL) suture to the standard 4:1 small-bite closure reduces incisional hernia incidence after colorectal cancer surgery.

Methods: This open parallel randomised controlled trial was conducted at two Swedish hospitals from 2017 to 2021. Patients aged 18 years or older, scheduled for elective colorectal cancer surgery through a midline incision, were randomised in a 1:1 ratio to either RTL and 4:1 small-bite closure with polypropylene sutures (RTL group) or 4:1 small-bite closure with polydioxanone suture alone (PDS group). The primary outcome was CT-detected incisional hernia at 1 year. Randomisation was stratified by study centre, and allocation was concealed using sequentially numbered sealed opaque envelopes. CT interpreters were blinded to treatment groups.

Results: A total of 160 patients were randomised, 80 in each group. At 1 year, 134 patients were analysed: 63 in the RTL group and 71 in the PDS group, using an intention-to-treat approach. Incisional hernia was found in 4 (6%) patients in the RTL group and 15 (21%) in the PDS group (OR 3.95, 95% CI 1.24 to 12.60; P = 0.014). No unintended effects were reported in either group.

Interpretation: Adding an RTL suture at fascial closure significantly reduced the incidence of incisional hernia in colorectal cancer surgery. Trial registration: NCT03390764. Funding: Not specified.
